dc:title: Is there a difference in the sugar composition of cultivated sweet fruits of tropical/subtropical and temperate origins?
dc:creator: Freeman C.
dc:description: In a sample of fruits of 57 cultivated species (25 temperate and 32 tropical/subtropical) sugar concentratios did not significantly differ. Tropical/subtropical species produce fruits significantly higher in disaccharides than fruits of temperate species. -from Authors

dc:title: The foliage-as-fruit hypothesis and the feeding behavior of South Asian ungulates
dc:creator: Dinerstein E.
dc:description: The foliage-as-fruit hypothesis argues that some plants may actually promote herbivory by large ungulates at the time of seed set to achieve seed dispersal. The author examines a minimum condition of this hypothesis, that large herbivores actually ingest and pass small seeds from non-fleshy-fruited plants, by screening the dung of large indigenous mammals at the time of seed set in a lowland reserve in S Nepal. He examined the dung of greater one-horned rhinoceros Rhinoceros unicornis, barking deer Muntiacus muntjac, hog deer Axis porcinus, axis deer Axis axis, sambar Cervus unicolor, and Indian bison or gaur Bos gaurus for seeds from plants not producing fleshy fruits, but found no obvious examples supporting the foliage-as-fruit hypothesis. Frequent, predictable, and widespread disturbance of grasslands by annual flooding and periodic fires provides sufficient microsites for the propagation of annual plants. -from Author

dc:title: Agonistic behavior by three-toed sloths, Bradypus variegatus
dc:creator: Greene H.W.
dc:description: A three-toed sloth rapidly ascended a cecropia tree, fought briefly and intensely with another adult male, and descended even more rapidly. The social system, visual abilities, and activity budgets of sloths are probably more complex than previously thought. -from Author

dc:title: Pollination biology in a tropical shrub community of the Venezuelan Guayana Highlands
dc:creator: Ramirez N.
dc:description: Of the 62 visiting agents recorded on 55 plant species, 80.6% are pollinators, 19.4% are visitors only. Four families of bees are represented. Pollen is normally carried on only 1 location, frequently ventral, although it can also be carried on the head or legs. Pollen transportation by wasps (4 families) is frequently ventral on the body and legs. Lepidopterans (3 families) carry pollen grains on their proboscis. Coleopterans are represented by 2 species of Scarabaeidae which transport pollen ventrally. They, as well as the dipterans, visit only 1 plant species. Three bird species visit plant species in the shrubland. Politmus milleri (Trochilidae) pollinates 7 plant species; pollen is transported on the beak and head feathers. At the community level, 56.2% of plant species are pollinated by hymenopterans, 10.9% by lepidopterans and 9.6% by dipterans, and 1 plant species (2.7%) by beetles. Bird-pollinated plants represent an important part of plants in the shrubland (12.3%). The anemophilous plants are 8.2% of total. From 148 species of visitors recorded on 49 zoophilous plant species, 37.6% of plant species are pollinated by medium size bees, 16.9% by large bees and 10.1% by small bees. Small wasps pollinate 8.1% and large wasps pollinate 6.1% of plant species. Large flies visit 1.4% and small flies 2.7% of plant species. -from English summary

dc:title: A tropical hawkmoth community: Costa Rican dry forest Sphingidae
dc:creator: Haber W.
dc:description: Hawkmoths were the primary pollinators of c10% of the tree species; they also pollinate various species of shrubs, herbs, lianas, and epiphytes. A total of 65 hawkmoth species were found, and 31 native plant species were adapted primarily for hawkmoth pollination. Abundance of both hawkmoths and hawkmoth flowers peaked in the first half of the wet season (May-July). Numbers of hawkmoths decreased through the dry season (December-April) with lowest numbers during April. Species of hawkmoth flowers also decreased through the dry season, but several species began flowering before onset of the wet season and before the sudden increase in hawkmoth numbers that followed shortly after the first rains. Tube lengths of hawkmoth flowers ranged from 0-19 cm (mean 5.1 cm), matched by the range in length of hawkmoth tongues (1-20 cm, mean 4.9 cm). Hawkmoth tongue lengths were correlated with body size (wing length). Long flower tubes restricted access to nectar to long-tongued moths, but hawkmoths visited many species of flowers adapted for other pollinator types (hummingbirds, bees, and bats) along with hawkmoth flowers whose tubes were much shorter than their tongue lengths. Some flowers were always heavily visited, other species were virtually ignored. In less attractive flowers, nectar accumulated during the night and attracted a variety of diurnal visitors the following morning. Hawkmoth flowers that opened before dark attracted diurnal and crepuscular visitors (bees, wasps, hummingbirds, butterflies) that robbed nectar and pollen, possibly decreasing flower attractiveness to hawkmoths. -from Authors

dc:title: Seasonal patterns in a tropical lowland forest
dc:creator: Boinski S.
dc:description: In a regenerating lowland wet forest at Corcovado National Park, Costa Rica, a major flush of new leaves occurred at the beginning of the wet season, a minor one towards the end of the wet season. Leaf fall and litter were greatest in the short dry season. Arthropod abundance was lowest in the middle of the wet season, probably due to the scarcity of new leaves and to the direct physical effects of torrential rains. Seasonal patterns of arthropod abundance varied among taxa, and among sampling methods; the arthropod fauna of dead, suspended leaves showed little seasonality. -from Authors

dc:title: Ecological impacts of selective logging in the Brazilian Amazon: a case study from the Paragominas region of the state of Para
dc:creator: Uhl C.
dc:description: Some 30-50 m3 of wood volume were removed per ha. equivalent to 4-8 trees per ha, or 1-2% of all tree stems ≥10 cm dbh. Total canopy cover was reduced from 80% to 45%, and 8% of the forest area was scarred by logging roads. If logging continues at its present rate, all of Para state could easily be logged within the next 80 yr. -from Authors

dc:title: Gut retention times of experimental pseudoseeds by emus
dc:creator: Willson M.
dc:description: Pseudoseeds (buttons and beads of a specific gravity within the range of real seeds) were retained in the digestive tract of captive Dromaius novaehollandiae very commonly for 1-2 d, but a considerable number were held for >1 wk (and up to several wk). Retention time did not vary consistently with pseudoseed dimensions but did differ greatly among birds and trials. Many of the ingested pseudoseeds were deposited at nightly camp sites. -from Author

dc:title: Differential predation of Welfia georgii seeds in treefall gaps and the forest understory
dc:creator: Schupp E.W.
dc:description: At La Selva, Costa Rica, seed survival of Welfia in gaps and beneath fruiting adults was very low, and significantly less than survival in the understory 10 m from an adult. Thus, the increase in survival with dispersal of seeds away from the parent is habitat-dependent. The difference is likely caused by the differential responses of various seed predator species to treefall gaps. -from Authors

dc:title: Prey capture by a West African social spider (Uloboridae: Philoponella sp.)
dc:creator: Breitwisch R.
dc:description: Studied in a wet lowland forest in S Cameroon, this species is atypical of uloborids in that the large web was not composed of individual orb webs. It captured insects cooperatively, including insects much larger than those captured by solitary species. However, the hypothesized positive relationship between the size of an insect and the number of spiders involved in its capture was not supported; even large insects were captured by only one to several juvenile spiders. Size of an insect and number of spiders feeding on it were positively correlated. There may be age- or size-related behavioral differences in prey capture with small juveniles throwing silk from above and lateral to the prey, and adults or large juveniles throwing silk and repairing holes beneath the prey. Mantids are dangerous insects to approach. -from Author

dc:title: Alternative foraging modes of orb web weaving spiders
dc:creator: Craig C.
dc:description: Large forest understory spiders build one large web per feeding period. Although their webs intercept more prey than webs built by small spiders, the biomass of captured prey relative to spider biomass is low. Small spiders build 3-5 webs per feeding period. The ratio of prey biomass intake relative to spider biomass, however is high. Small spiders may be able to tolerate high rates of web loss because of their potentially high rate of prey intake, but for large spiders, the high rates of web loss may not be tolerable because of the low rate of prey biomass intake. -from Author

dc:title: Nests of the myrmecophilous stingless bee, Trigona moorei: how do bees initiate their nest within a arboreal ant nest?
dc:creator: Sakagami S.
dc:description: All 67 nests collected in the Province of Sumatera Barat, Indonesia, were found within active arboreal carton nests of Crematogaster ants. The process of nest founding is presumed to be: deposition of resin on vegetation near the target ant nest and preparation of entrance initiation on the ant nest surface; preparation of a sticky entrance tube on the ant nest and its extension into the ant nest as an inner tunnel; preparation of an ant-free area in the ant nest and a primordial nest cavity wall, covered by resin; further extension of the nest cavity by continuous replacement of the cavity wall, even after the end of swarming and start of queen oviposition; and thickening of the cavity wall after the nest cavity has reached full size. -from Authors

dc:title: Population structure, dispersion and microhabitat regeneration of Carapa guianensis in northeastern Brazil
dc:creator: Henriques R.P.B.
dc:description: Censused all seedlings, saplings and adults in 0.1024 ha of Carapa guianensis (Meliaceae), a local dominant tropical canopy tree in the forest near Sao Luis, Maranhao. Estimated adult density was 137 individuals/ha, but only 31% of adults were >44.9 cm dbh. The size class distribution of diameters was continuous. Based on Morisita's Index seedlings and juveniles (≤1.4 cm dbh) had the dispersion pattern of a population with "point sources'. Subadults (>1.4 cm and ≤15.9 cm dbh) and adults (>15.9 cm dbh) showed a random dispersion pattern for all quadrat sizes. Seedling and juvenile per capita recruitment were negatively correlated with number of adults and adult basal area per quadrat. The per capita recruitment of subadults was also negatively correlated with adult basal area per quadrat. The lower per capita recruitment with increasing adult abundance was attributed to high mortality caused by predators, pathogens or adult interference. -from Authors

dc:title: Breakage and regrowth of Piper species in rain forest understory
dc:creator: Gartner B.
dc:description: Species of Piper in the lowland tropical forest of La Selva, Costa Rica, appear to have many adaptations to avoid death resulting from branches being broken of pinned to the ground. Analysis of breakages scars along the branches shows that the majority of the individuals have at least one broken branch; some have many more. Breakage is lower in open habitat, and is similar within gap edge, secondary and primary forest habitats. Almost all the individuals of the majority of the species showed growth after having their branches pinned to the ground with wire for 22-24 days. Over 40% of the plants had been propagated vegetatively; this is a conservative estimate. -from Author

dc:title: Geographic variation and community structure in an ant-plant mutualism: Azteca and Cecropia in Costa Rica
dc:creator: Longino J.
dc:description: A survey of ant communities found in Costa Rica revealed a community of Azteca species obligately associated with Cecropia, and a diverse assemblage of non-obligate ants in a variety of genera. High occupation rates of Cecropia saplings and trees, and presence of many incipient colonies in saplings vs single colonies in trees, suggest that Cecropia are a limiting resource for which ants compete. Obligate Azteca appeared competitively superior to non-obligate ants. Local communities contained 3-4 Azteca species using the same host tree species resource. Two Azteca species had a parapatric distribution, the zone of parpatry cooccurring with a similar zone of parapatry between 2 Cecropia species. At the boundary. the Azteca species were not host specific. Possible factors influencing the outcome of competition between ants for Cecropia trees include queen and worker behavior, priority effects, partial hostplant specialization, and habitat specialization. -from Author

dc:title: Zonation in mangrove and salt marsh vegetation at Laguna de Mecoacan, Mexico
dc:creator: Lopez-Portillo J.
dc:description: Examined 2 mangrove (Avicennia germinans, Rhizophora mangle) and 3 salt marsh species (Batis maritima, Spartina spartinae, Pithecellobium lanceolatum). In a undisturbed transect, soil physico-chemical characteristics changed continuously with relief, whereas the relation between cover and height of A. germinans and relief changed in a discrete manner. During the wet, high water level season, variation in salinity was unrelated to relief. In a disturbed transect, B. maritima occupies the mudflat from which A. germinans trees were removed by clear-cutting at least 16 yr ago. Although a physiological response might account for the low Avicennia cover and height in the hinterland. Batis is probably excluded by Avicennia from the mudflat, the result being the observed zonation. -from Authors

dc:title: Distribution and ecology of vascular epiphytes in lowland rain forest of Guyana
dc:creator: Ter Steege H.
dc:description: Studied the distribution and ecology of vascular (hemi)epiphytes on standing canopy trees in walaba forest, greenheart forest and mixed forest. Differences in epiphytic vegetation appeared to be correlated with humidity conditions as determined by the soil, and with the tree species (host preference). Crowns are much richer than the trunks in epiphytic species and individuals. Bryophyte mats and accumulated debris in the lower canopy support a different vascular epiphytic vegetation than the middle and upper canopy branches, where the predominant epiphytes are adapted to drought and for growing on twigs. -from Authors

dc:title: A comparison of methods for sampling ants (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) in savannas
dc:creator: Romero H.
dc:description: Hand collecting of ants, sampling all ants in a specific area, and collection with pitfall traps baited with meat, tuna, honey, or with unbaited traps were compared with respect to efficiency in assessing species diversity and abundance in the Venezuelan Llanos. Hand collecting for over 8 hr was the most time-efficient and reliable technique for estimating number of species. Intensive sampling of ants in a small area proved to be the least efficient. Best results were obtained by a combination of hand collecting and pitfall traps. -from Authors

dc:title: Nest site selection by the exotic chestnut mannikin (Lonchura malacca) in Puerto Rico
dc:creator: Burger J.
dc:description: Chestnut mannikin, recently introduced in Puerto Rico, is a widespread Southeast Asian species. In its native habitat it frequently nests in vegetation over water, but in Puerto Rico it usually nests in dense sugar cane. In a march ecosystem in Humacao, mannikins nest in clumps of Cyperus spp. growing on top of stumps in a lagoon. Nests are in sedge clumps that are in shallower water and on higher stumps, and that are taller, wider and denser than clumps without mannikin nests. Nests were usually placed on the south side of the clump, with the entrance facing open water. The predator protection offered by nesting over water may account for nests being placed in relatively open sites. -Authors

dc:title: Longevity of individual flowers in a Costa Rican cloud forest: ecological correlates and phylogenetic constraints
dc:creator: Stratton D.
dc:description: Mean individual flower longevity (MFL) was determined for 110 species at Monteverde. Taxonomic constraints at the family level were the most important determinant of flower longevity. Family membership explained 73% of the variance in floral longevity compared to 2.6% among genera within families. There were trends in flower longevity associated with various ecological factors hypothesized to be important: bee-pollinated species had lower MFL than hummingbird and moth-pollinated species; MFL was negatively correlated with plant size (trees<shrubs<herbs); large flowers persisted longer than small flowers; MFL was higher in species with ≥50 ovules per flower than in species with few ovules. However, when correlations due to taxonomic relatedness were eliminated, none of the ecological factors had a significant effect on flower longevity. There was no difference in MFL in 2 climatically distinct communities surveyed. Overall mean flower longevity (2.7 days) falls midway between that of tropical lowland species (1 day) and montane species (4-8 days). -from Author

dc:title: Breeding systems and genetic diversity in Acacia auriculiformis and A. crassicarpa
dc:creator: Moran G.
dc:description: These acacias may have smaller effective population sizes than have been found in many other trees. Both species have high levels of outcrossing with little variation in the outcrossing rate between populations. -from Authors

dc:title: Responses by red-bellied tamarins (Saguinus labiatus) to fecal scents of predatory and non-predatory neotropical mammals
dc:creator: Caine N.G.
dc:description: Methylene chloride extracts of the feces of jaguar Panthera onca, margay Felis wiedi, jaguarundi Herpailurus yagouaroundi, tapir Tapirus terrestris, paca Cuniculus paca and agouti Dasyprocta fuliginosa were presented to tamarins. Chemicals from predators elicited more sniffing and avoidance than did those of the non-predators or controls. Tamarins gave alarm calls to margay scent, a response not observed with the other extracts. The responses to predator chemicals were exhibited by captive-born individuals, suggesting that experience with a predator is not necessary. -from Authors

dc:title: Vertebrate dispersal syndromes in some Australian and New Zealand plant communities, with geographic comparisons
dc:creator: Willson M.F.
dc:description: Fleshy fruits, apparently adapted for consumption by vertebrate seed-dispersal agents, are very common (often >70% of the species) in most tropical and subtropical rain forests. Fleshy fruits are moderately common in some north-temperate forests (up to 50% of the species) and some south-temperate moist forests (New Zealand 27-60%, Chile 45-70%). Less than 30% of the species of most Australian sclerophyll woodlands, heaths, and alpine communities have fleshy fruits. Wooded vegetation types in New Zealand average 19-56% of species with fleshy fruits. Shrublands in many regions vary greatly, and grasslands commonly have low frequencies of fleshy fruited species. Fruits suitable for consumption by volant dispersers are much more common than those suited for nonvolant dispersers in North American, Chilean, Queensland, and South African forests; in Neotropical forests fruits carried by flying vertebrates are somewhat more common than others, and in Gabon, fruits consumed by nonvolant dispersers outnumber those eaten by flying dispersal agents. The proportion of species with fleshy fruits frequently correlates with moisture availability, but correlations with latitude, soil nutrients and succession also have been reported. Fleshy fruits are more commonly produced by shrubs, sometimes vines, than by trees or herbs in North American forests, some European forests and scrublands, and drier tropical forests. Most bird-dispersed fruits appear red or black (to human eyes). Mammal-dispersed fruits are often brown, green, orange or yellow. -from Authors

dc:title: Nest tree selectivity by the tropical ant, Paraponera clavata
dc:creator: Belk M.C.
dc:description: Paraponera clavata is a large, arboreal foraging, ground nesting, ant which appears to rely heavily upon nectar from extra-floral nectaries. In a Costa Rican forest this ant built nests at the base of 10 species of trees but preferentially selects the tree Pentaclethra macroloba. In Panama, P. clavata nests were found at the base of 76 species of trees and shrubs, 1 palm, and 2 lianas on a 50 ha forest plot. Buttressing and extra-floral nectaries, conspicuous features of nest trees in Costa Rica, were not so in Panama. -from Authors

dc:title: Geographic and seasonal variation in fragrance choices and preferences of male euglossine bees
dc:creator: Ackerman J.
dc:description: Variation in choices and preferences for fragrances are examined for a large portion of the euglossine bee assemblages of Barro Colorado Island and Cerro Campana, Panama. -from Author

dc:title: Insect herbivory on a tropical understory tree: effects of leaf age and habitat
dc:creator: Ernest K.
dc:description: Variability in the extent and patterns of insect herbivory on leaves of Pentagonia donnell-smithii (Rubiaceae) was quantified with respect to leaf age and habitat type (sites) in lowland tropical wet forest in Costa Rica. Rates of herbivory were higher for young than for mature leaves. The common leaf beetle, Phanaeta sp. (prob. ruficollis, Chrysomelidae) preferred young leaves, but another herbivore (the seed bug, Nicuesa speciosa) preferred mature leaves in a choice test. Total rates of herbivory over a 10-day period were higher in a secondary forest site than in successional plots 1-5 yr old. Phanaeta sp. preference for leaves from younger, more open sites was not explained by either leaf toughness or leaf water content. -from Author

dc:title: Natural regeneration of an autochonous species of the Guyana forest: Eperua falcata Aublet - Caesalpinaceae
dc:creator: Forget P.M.
dc:description: Flowering occurs during the dry season and fruits mature during the humid season. Seeds are dispersed when humidity decreases enough to promote bursting of the pod. Nearly 60% of seeds fall <10 m from the parent tree; maximum dispersal distance is 30 m. Seeds are slowly eaten, and predation by rodents (the principal predators) is not distance-dependent. Desynchronisation of flowering and consequent production of fruits during the dry season is followed by high rates of abortion and seed predation. Seedling mortality is low and their distribution under and around the parent tree is nearly the same as that of the seeds. Seedlings maintain themselves during a long time under closed canopy and a small increase of light intensity permits growth in height of several cm a year. Annual mortality of small seedlings is higher and growth rates is slower than those of large seedlings. Saplings are principally located 10-15 m from the nearest parent tree, but outside the limit of the crown. This distance corresponds to half the distance between 2 adjacent trees, on average. This, in turn, corresponds with the major population recruitment zone of Eperua falcata, maintaining this species at a high density. -from English summary

dc:title: Elevational patterns of species richness, evenness, and abundance of the Costa Rican leaf-litter herpetofauna
dc:creator: Fauth J.
dc:description: Species richness was positively correlated with leaf-litter depth, and negatively correlated with elevation. Herpetofaunal density also tended to increase with litter depth and decline with elevation. A strong positive correlation existed between species richness and herpetofauna density. Evenness was highly variable and independent of both leaf-litter depth and elevation. Local herpetofaunas typically consist of a few very common species along with a large number of comparatively rare species. -from Authors

dc:title: Primate seed dispersal: the fate of dispersed seeds
dc:creator: Chapman C.
dc:description: The primate species of Santa Rosa National Park, Costa Rica (Ateles geoffroyi, Alouatta palliata, Cebus capucinus) have diets in which fruits are major components. All 3 species defecated seeds of many fruiting species, of which 60% germinated under experimental conditions. On average, 392 large seeds that passed through the stomachs of monkeys fell weekly per hectare of forest floor, but the dispersal performed by the primates may not be the final stage of dispersal for many of these seeds. Some 51.8% of seeds were either removed by secondary dispersers, or killed by seed predators within 5 days of being placed in the forest. Rate of seed removal varied depending on the seed species. -from Author

dc:title: Measurement of the dispersal of large seeds and fruits with a magnetic locator
dc:creator: Alverson W.
dc:description: Magnets weighing 2.2 and 0.25g were inserted into palm fruits, and the fruits hidden in 0.01-ha plots at the La Selva Biological Station in Costa Rica. Using a magnetic locator, the authors recovered 99.5% of marked fruits that were hidden on the soil surface or buried to 10 cm deep. The larger magnets were detectable 100% of the time, even when buried to 40 cm. Search times of 20 to 40 h per hectare would allow recovery of 99% of marked seeds and fruits. -from Authors

dc:title: Environmental factors related to the occurrence of mound-building nasute termites in Trachypogon savannas of the Orinoco Llanos
dc:creator: San Jose J.J.
dc:description: Analysed ecological variables as the best indicators of a given area's suitability for support of terrestrial Velocitermes and/or Nasutitermes species. Soil physical variables determining water balance during critical dry periods were of paramount value for the successful establishment of mound-building nasute termites. -from Authors

dc:title: Seasonal and spatial variation in the light environment in a tropical dipterocarp forest and gaps
dc:creator: Raich J.
dc:description: Mean weekly photosynthetic photon flux densities (PPFD) in the forest and in the small and large gap sites averaged 1.9, 8.3 and 37% respectively of the PPFD in the open. There was no apparent seasonality of PPFD in the open, but there was pronounced seasonal variation of PPFD in the forest and gap sites. Therefore, seedlings within forest gaps may be exposed to very different light regimes over the course of the year. Mean daily PPFD was highly correlated with canopy coverage in both short-term and long-term experiments. A short-term study indicated that light penetrating through canopy openings can increase the PPFD near ground level at least 20 m inside the forest from the nearest gap. -from Author

dc:title: Effects of logging, drought, and fire on structure and composition of tropical forests in Sabah, Malaysia
dc:creator: Woods P.
dc:description: Extensive tracts of tropical rain forest were burnt in Borneo during the El Nino drought of 1983. Severe droughts have occurred previously but without causing such extensive fires. This extensive burning is a result of forests becoming more fire-prone after disturbance by logging. Rates of tree mortality after drought and fire ranged from 38-94% in logged forests and 19-71% in unlogged forests, while for saplings rates of mortality exceeded 80% in both forest types. Secondary succession after logging was truncated by fire with the result that the post-fire condition of a forest logged 6 yr before fire was similar to that of a forest logged 2 yr before fire. The impact of fire differs from other natural or man-made gap forming processes in that most pre-existing seedlings and saplings are killed by fire. This left the regrowth in burnt forest depauperate in species diversity and in regeneration of upper-canopy species. Logged and burnt forests suffered severe canopy loss and the ground cover was dominated by grasses (eg Imperata cylindrica) or woody creepers (eg Eupatorium odoratum). In burnt primary forest, however, canopy loss was less severe and there was a low density of grasses. The prospects for recovery of forest structure appear to be good in burnt primary forest although species composition may be permanently altered. In forests logged prior to the fire, however, prospects for recovery of forest structure are not good, especially if further burning occurs. Recovery of these forests depends heavily on the ability of the secondary tree species to shade out the vigorous grasses, the continued presence of which may herald the conversion of the forest to unproductive grassland as has occurred widely elsewhere in the tropics after over-intensive shifting cultivation. -Author

dc:title: Nest site selection in zenaida dove (Zenaida aurita) in Puerto Rico
dc:creator: Burger J.
dc:description: In the Culebra National Wildlife Refuge, bridled (Sterna annaethetus and roseate (Sterna dougallii) terns used particular parts of islands, but zenaida doves nest in all available habitats. Doves nested on flatter places near taller rocks, on less visible places farther from clearings, and closer to tern nest than were the random points. On Cayo de Agua doves nested mainly in rock crevices; on Cayo Raton they nested mainly on the ground under vegetation. Doves may derive antipredator advantages from nesting near terns. -from Authors

dc:title: The reproductive cycle of Norops uniformis (Sauria: Iguanidae) in Veracruz, Mexico
dc:creator: Campbell J.
dc:description: Average body size (snout-vent length) of males and females increased at the beginning of, and peaked during, the early rainy season with a decline as the dry season approached. Gravid females were found in all months for which samples were available (March through October). Egg production increased dramatically during the early rainy season and exhibited a marked decline immediately prior to the dry season. -from Authors

dc:title: On nest densities of the leaf-cutting ant Atta cephalotes in tropical primary forest
dc:creator: Jaffe K.
dc:description: In the Orinoco-Amazon basin Atta cephalotes occurred at a maximal density of only 0.045 nests per ha. The number of clearings in the forest may be the limiting factor for colonization of new forest sites by A. cephalotes. -from Authors

dc:title: Thermoregulatory influences on the ecology of two sympatric varanids in Sri Lanka
dc:creator: Wikramanayake E.
dc:description: Varanus salvator and V. bengalensis were studied in S Sri Lanka. V. salvator was active by early morning but sought shade in the afternoon; any afternoon activity was in an aquatic environment. Although the regression of V. salvator cloacal temperatures on daytime ambient temperatures is significant and indicate thermoconformity, they maintain a relatively stable body temperature behaviorally by selecting appropriate thermal microhabitats. During the night they sought stable thermal microhabitats under dense bushes, thickets, and even in water (which is warmer than the night air temperature). This presumably enabled them to be active early the following morning. V. bengalensis began activity later in the day and tend to elevate body temperatures by basking. They also forage in the open thus thermoregulating while feeding. By evening they retreat into burrows and other refugia where body temperatures drop below air temperatures. -from Authors

dc:title: Observations on a commensal relationship of the microhylid frog Chiasmocleis ventrimaculata and the burrowing theraphosid spider Xenesthis immanis in southeastern Peru
dc:creator: Cocroft R.
dc:description: Both species simultaneously utilize the same diurnal retreats and forage in overlapping areas. Feeding trials suggest that Xenesthis readily feed on some species of anurans, and observations implicate the role of chemical defenses in preventing Xenesthis predation on Chiasmocleis. -from Authors

dc:title: Seed and seedling production in Pandanus tectorius
dc:creator: Lee M.
dc:description: Pandanus tectorius, a tree of strand habitats that is dispersed by drift, was studied in Moorea, French Polynesia. It produces fruit with 2-10 carpels. Seed/carpel ratio was inversely related to the number of carpels in a fruit. Most fruit contained multiple seeds. Fruit in the high-light environment produced a larger proportion of multiple seedlings (44.8%) than fruit in the shaded area (23.8%). Multiple seedlings from a single fruit were not smaller than single seedlings in the high-light environment, but were significantly smaller in the shaded area. -from Author

dc:title: Associations of vascular epiphytes in a Guatemalan cloud forest
dc:creator: Catling P.
dc:description: Of the 68 species recorded, the largest groups were the Orchidaceae (29 species) and the Polypodiaceae (18 species). Analyses revealed associations of small, closely related species on smaller and consequently younger trunks, and associations of larger, less closely related species on larger (older) trunks. The associations of small species possess characteristics correlated with the earlier stages of plant succession and the density-independent and non-equilibrium diversity model. The associations of larger species possess characteristics correlated with the later stages of plant succession and appear to approach equilibrium in species composition. -from Authors

dc:title: Leaf, stem, and metamer characteristics of vines in a tropical deciduous forest in Jalisco, Mexico
dc:creator: Castellanos A.E.
dc:description: Leaf weight and specific leaf weight were significantly lower in vines than in tree species at the same site. For both vines and trees at Chamela, specific leaf weight values are among the lowest values reported in the literature. Leaf N concentration was higher in trees than in woody vines. A relationship was found between leaf structural characteristics and nutrient concentration for all growth forms that was reflected in part in the specific leaf weight. Relative leaf weight ratio (the ratio of leaf to stem internode weight) and internode length were related to the specific vine growth forms; other morphological features were not. Large compensatory changes in stem density and volume, as well as in leaf weight, resulted in similar metamer weights among vine species of different growth habits. -from Authors

dc:title: Nitrification rates in two undisturbed tropical rain forests and three slash-and-burn sites of the Venezuelan Amazon
dc:creator: Montagnini F.
dc:description: Nitrification was higher in the soils of slash-and-burn sites than in undisturbed forests. Rates of nitrate production were 14.9 mg/kg/30 days in a forest on an Oxisol, 3.5 mg/kg/30 days in a forest on Ultisol, 23.2 mg/kg/30 days in a 1.5-yr-old slash-and-burn agricultural site on an Oxisol, 12.9 mg/kg/30 days in a 0.5-yr-old slash-and-burn agricultural site on Ultisol, and 12.1 mg/kg/30 days in a 3.0-yr-old pasture on Ultisol. In the undisturbed forests, rates of nitrate production in the root mat averaged 93.5 mg/kg/30 days on Oxisols and 11.2 mg/kg/30 days on Ultisols. Ammonium availability appears to regulate nitrification in both site types. -from Authors

dc:title: Identification and distribution of C3 and C4 grasses in open and shaded habitats in Sao Paulo State, Brazil
dc:creator: Klink C.
dc:description: Of the 78 species collected, 48 sun species and 7 shade species possessed the C4 pathway; 23 species possessed the C3 pathway, of which 3 were sun species and 20 were shade species. C4 species are thus more abundant in open habitats and C3 species in shaded habitats. The data also show the taxonomic distribution of the photosynthetic pathways. All genera of the collected species are exclusively C3 or C4, except Panicum which has both C3 and C4 species. -from Authors

dc:title: Leaf toughness affects leaf harvesting by the leaf cutter ant, Atta cephalotes (L.) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
dc:creator: Nichols-Orians C.M.
dc:description: Old leaves were nearly 4 times tougher than younger leaves within a single tree canopy (Rubiaceae) exploited by leaf cutter ants. Ant workers cutting old leaves had significantly greater head capsule widths than those choosing to cut the young leaves; nonetheless, the cutting rates for all workers were significantly slower on older leaves. The apparent inability of the majority of workers to cut older leaves would make young leaves more valuable to a nest. -from Authors

dc:title: Decomposition of foliage in various successional tropical vegetation types
dc:creator: Babbar L.I.
dc:description: To evaluate the effect of foliage type on decomposition, the authors monitored the decay of a representative mix of autochthonous leaves in: 2-yr-old successional vegetation; a community that mimicked the physiognomy and species richness of successional vegetation; and a young plantation of the tree Cordia alliodora. Foliage of the imitation of succession decayed most rapidly, losing half of its mass, N, P, K, Ca, and Mg and S in 1-3 wk. Foliage of successional vegetation decayed more slowly, losing half of its initial mass and initial contents of all elements except N and S in 2-6 wk. Leaves of the tree grown in monoculture decomposed very slowly, losing only 22% of their mass, and <50% of all elements monitored except K and P, during 15 wk. Mass loss and loss of N, Ca, and Mg were significantly faster in the bare plot than in vegetated plots, but differences in decay among foliage types were much greater than differences among ecosystems. Sustained nutrition of the successional mimic may depend heavily on rapid uptake of mineralized nutrients, whereas recalcitrant litter may slow recycling in plantations of C. alliodora. -from English summary

dc:title: Seed survival in the palm Astrocaryum standleyanum: evidence for dependence upon its seed dispersers
dc:creator: Smythe N.
dc:description: If seeds of the Neotropical forest palm Astrocaryum standleyanum are not peeled and buried (in the manner followed by their principal disperser, agouti Dasyprocta punctata) the probability of their survival is greatly reduced. In peeling the fruits, agoutis may be removing invertebrate larvae before they have had time to penetrate the endocarp of the seed. Because of its abundance, because its fruiting is relatively predictable and because the seeds, when stored, remain intact through the annual period of scarcity, A. standleyanum constitutes an important food resource for several mammal species in he Panamanian forests. -from Author

dc:title: Competition among ants for myrmecophytes and the significance of plant trichomes
dc:creator: Davidson D.
dc:description: Data on founding queens and established ant colonies of 8 Peruvian rain forest myrmecophytes suggest that ants compete interspecifically for host plants. Plant-ants show negative interspecific associations on plants with actively foraging colonies, but not on plant housing only founding queens or incipient colonies. In several ant-plants, small and large individuals regularly have different ants. One ant species may deterministically replace another over time on Clidemia heterophylla, but the pattern may have different explanations in other myremecophytes. Among 5 myrmecophytes with long, dense stem trichomes, sizes of the most frequent ant associates are positively correlated with trichome spacing. Ants larger than a threshold body size cannot move readily through the trichomes without first cutting trail networks. Many obligate plant-ants appear to be species requiring special forms of protection from competing and predatory ants. Preferential nesting by such ants on plants with protective trichomes may explain the frequent co-occurrence of inhibitory trichomes and domatia in a number of ant-plant genera. -Authors

dc:title: Measurement of atmospheric deposition at tree canopy level in a subtropical premontane wet forest, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
dc:creator: Brown I.F.
dc:description: To measure variations in deposition to a forested basin near Rio de Janeiro we employed a simple technique of mounting collectors above the tree canopy. Experiments showed that the differences between means from such collectors as compared to those from collectors in clearings were <5%, <3%, and <17% for rainfall, sodium, and acidic deposition, respectively. The primary sources of sodium and acidity were from outside the basin. Deposition rates were positively skewed; a few events dominated mean annual deposition. Rainfall and acidic deposition were uniformly distributed in the basin, while sodium varied significantly. Thus, the distribution of collectors necessary to characterize atmospheric input to this type of forest depends both on the site and the component to be studied. -from Authors

dc:title: Mercury contamination in the Madeira River, Amazon - Hg inputs to the environment
dc:creator: De Lacerda L.
dc:description: The potential contamination of Amazon rivers by mercury used in gold-mining activity has recently worried various local and international environmental authorities. Because of the great quantities of Hg involved, the complex ecology of Amazonian ecosystems and the socio-economy of the local population, generally based on fishery resources, are at risk. Presents the first estimates of Hg inputs to the regional environment, describes the evolution of the problem, and discusses its eventual impact on the local biota and human population. -from Authors
